3.passage:
She took down a jar from one of the shelves as she passed; it was labelled "ORANGE MARMALADE", but to her great disappointment it was empty: she did not like to drop the jar for fear of killing somebody underneath, so managed to put it into one of the cupboards as she fell past it.

"Well!" thought [MASK] to herself, "after such a fall as this, I shall think nothing of tumbling down stairs! How brave they'll all think me at home!

5.passage: Would the fall _never_ come to an end? "I wonder how many miles I've fallen by this time?" [MASK] said aloud.

8.passage: Presently [MASK] began again. "I wonder if I shall fall right _through_ the earth! How funny it'll seem to come out among the people that walk with their heads downward! The Antipathies, I think--" (she was rather glad there _was_ no one listening, this time, as it didn't sound at all the right word) "--but I shall have to ask them what the name of the country is, you know.

13.passage: But do cats eat bats, I wonder?" And here [MASK] began to get rather sleepy, and went on saying to herself, in a dreamy sort of way, "Do cats eat bats? Do cats eat bats?" and sometimes, "Do bats eat cats?" for, you see, as she couldn't answer either question, it didn't much matter which way she put it.

25.passage: And so it was indeed: she was now only ten inches high, and her face brightened up at the thought that she was now the right size for going through the little door into that lovely garden. First, however, she waited for a few minutes to see if she was going to shrink any further: she felt a little nervous about this; "for it might end, you know," said [MASK] to herself, "in my going out altogether, like a candle. I wonder what I should be like then?" And she tried to fancy what the flame of a candle is like after the candle is blown out, for she could not remember ever having seen such a thing.

29.passage:
She generally gave herself very good advice, (though she very seldom followed it), and sometimes she scolded herself so severely as to bring tears into her eyes; and once she remembered trying to box her own ears for having cheated herself in a game of croquet she was playing against herself, for this curious child was very fond of pretending to be two people. "But it's no use now," thought [MASK], "to pretend to be two people! Why, there's hardly enough of me left to make _one_ respectable person!"

Soon her eye fell on a little glass box that was lying under the table: she opened it, and found in it a very small cake, on which the words "EAT ME" were beautifully marked in currants.

30.passage:
Soon her eye fell on a little glass box that was lying under the table: she opened it, and found in it a very small cake, on which the words "EAT ME" were beautifully marked in currants. "Well, I'll eat it," said [MASK], "and if it makes me grow larger, I can reach the key; and if it makes me grow smaller, I can creep under the door; so either way I'll get into the garden, and I don't care which happens!"

She ate a little bit, and said anxiously to herself, "Which way?

34.passage:
*      *      *      *      *      *      *

    *      *      *      *      *      *

*      *      *      *      *      *      *




CHAPTER II. The Pool of Tears


"Curiouser and curiouser!" cried [MASK] (she was so much surprised, that for the moment she quite forgot how to speak good English); "now I'm opening out like the largest telescope that ever was! Good-bye, feet!" (for when she looked down at her feet, they seemed to be almost out of sight, they were getting so far off).

36.passage:
you can;--but I must be kind to them," thought [MASK], "or perhaps they won't walk the way I want to go! Let me see: I'll give them a new pair of boots every Christmas."

And she went on planning to herself how she would manage it.

37.passage: And she went on planning to herself how she would manage it. "They must go by the carrier," [MASK] thought; "and how funny it'll seem, sending presents to one's own feet! And how odd the directions will look!

41.passage:
It was as much as she could do, lying down on one side, to look through into the garden with one eye; but to get through was more hopeless than ever: she sat down and began to cry again.

"You ought to be ashamed of yourself," said [MASK], "a great girl like you," (she might well say this), "to go on crying in this way! Stop this moment, I tell you!" But she went on all the same, shedding gallons of tears, until there was a large pool all round her, about four inches deep and reaching half down the hall.

52.passage:
She got up and went to the table to measure herself by it, and found that, as nearly as she could guess, she was now about two feet high, and was going on shrinking rapidly: she soon found out that the cause of this was the fan she was holding, and she dropped it hastily, just in time to avoid shrinking away altogether.

"That _was_ a narrow escape!" said [MASK], a good deal frightened at the sudden change, but very glad to find herself still in existence; "and now for the garden!" and she ran with all speed back to the little door: but, alas!

55.passage:
and she ran with all speed back to the little door: but, alas! the little door was shut again, and the little golden key was lying on the glass table as before, "and things are worse than ever," thought [MASK], "for I never was so small as this before, never! And I declare it's too bad, that it is!"

As she said these words her foot slipped, and in another moment, splash!

57.passage:
However, she soon made out that she was in the pool of tears which she had wept when she was nine feet high.

"I wish I hadn't cried so much!" said [MASK], as she swam about, trying to find her way out. "I shall be punished for it now, I suppose, by being drowned in my own tears!

59.passage:
Just then she heard something splashing about in the pool a little way off, and she swam nearer to make out what it was: at first she thought it must be a walrus or hippopotamus, but then she remembered how small she was now, and she soon made out that it was only a mouse that had slipped in like herself.

"Would it be of any use, now," thought [MASK], "to speak to this mouse? Everything is so out-of-the-way down here, that I should think very likely it can talk: at any rate, there's no harm in trying.

74.passage:
We indeed!" cried the Mouse, who was trembling down to the end of his tail. "As if _I_ would talk on such a subject! Our family always _hated_ cats: nasty, low, vulgar things! Don't let me hear the name again!"

"I won't indeed!" said [MASK], in a great hurry to change the subject of conversation.

144.passage: This speech caused a remarkable sensation among the party. Some of the birds hurried off at once: one old Magpie began wrapping itself up very carefully, remarking, "I really must be getting home; the night-air doesn't suit my throat!" and a Canary called out in a trembling voice to its children, "Come away, my dears! It's high time you were all in bed!" On various pretexts they all moved off, and [MASK] was soon left alone.

161.passage:
There ought to be a book written about me, that there ought! And when I grow up, I'll write one--but I'm grown up now," she added in a sorrowful tone; "at least there's no room to grow up any more _here_."

"But then," thought [MASK], "shall I _never_ get any older than I am now?

181.passage: This time there were _two_ little shrieks, and more sounds of broken glass. "What a number of cucumber-frames there must be!" thought [MASK]. "I wonder what they'll do next!

202.passage:
And yet what a dear little puppy it was!" said [MASK], as she leant against a buttercup to rest herself, and fanned herself with one of the leaves: "I should have liked teaching it tricks very much, if--if I'd only been the right size to do it! Oh dear! I'd nearly forgotten that I've got to grow up again! Let me see--how _is_ it to be managed? I suppose I ought to eat or drink something or other; but the great question is, what?"

The great question certainly was, what?

222.passage:
Here was another puzzling question; and as [MASK] could not think of any good reason, and as the Caterpillar seemed to be in a _very_ unpleasant state of mind, she turned away.

"Come back!" the Caterpillar called after her.

223.passage:
the Caterpillar called after her. "I've something important to say!"

This sounded promising, certainly: [MASK] turned and came back again.

225.passage:
Keep your temper," said the Caterpillar.

"Is that all?" said [MASK], swallowing down her anger as well as she could.

"No," said the Caterpillar.

232.passage: Well, I've tried to say "How doth the little busy bee," but it all came different!" [MASK] replied in a very melancholy voice.

239.passage:
it asked.

"Oh, I'm not particular as to size," [MASK] hastily replied; "only one doesn't like changing so often, you know."

"I _don't_ know," said the Caterpillar.

243.passage:
Are you content now?" said the Caterpillar.

"Well, I should like to be a _little_ larger, sir, if you wouldn't mind," said [MASK]: "three inches is such a wretched height to be."

"It is a very good height indeed!" said the Caterpillar angrily, rearing itself upright as it spoke (it was exactly three inches high).

255.passage: What _can_ all that green stuff be?" said [MASK]. "And where _have_ my shoulders got to? And oh, my poor hands, how is it I can't see you?" She was moving them about as she spoke, but no result seemed to follow, except a little shaking among the distant green leaves.

259.passage:
Let me alone!"

"Serpent, I say again!" repeated the Pigeon, but in a more subdued tone, and added with a kind of sob, "I've tried every way, and nothing seems to suit them!"

"I haven't the least idea what you're talking about," said [MASK].

270.passage:
But I'm _not_ a serpent, I tell you!" said [MASK]. "I'm a--I'm a--"

"Well! _What_ are you?" said the Pigeon.

272.passage:
What_ are you?" said the Pigeon. "I can see you're trying to invent something!"

"I--I'm a little girl," said [MASK], rather doubtfully, as she remembered the number of changes she had gone through that day.

275.passage:
A likely story indeed!" said the Pigeon in a tone of the deepest contempt. "I've seen a good many little girls in my time, but never _one_ with such a neck as that! No, no! You're a serpent; and there's no use denying it. I suppose you'll be telling me next that you never tasted an egg!"

"I _have_ tasted eggs, certainly," said [MASK], who was a very truthful child; "but little girls eat eggs quite as much as serpents do, you know.

285.passage: As she said this, she came suddenly upon an open place, with a little house in it about four feet high. "Whoever lives there," thought [MASK], "it'll never do to come upon them _this_ size: why, I should frighten them out of their wits!" So she began nibbling at the righthand bit again, and did not venture to go near the house till she had brought herself down to nine inches high.

290.passage:
[MASK] went timidly up to the door, and knocked.

"There's no sort of use in knocking," said the Footman, "and that for two reasons. First, because I'm on the same side of the door as you are; secondly, because they're making such a noise inside, no one could possibly hear you." And certainly there _was_ a most extraordinary noise going on within--a constant howling and sneezing, and every now and then a great crash, as if a dish or kettle had been broken to pieces.

291.passage:
And certainly there _was_ a most extraordinary noise going on within--a constant howling and sneezing, and every now and then a great crash, as if a dish or kettle had been broken to pieces.

"Please, then," said [MASK], "how am I to get in?"

"There might be some sense in your knocking," the Footman went on without attending to her, "if we had the door between us.

297.passage: But perhaps he can't help it," she said to herself; "his eyes are so _very_ nearly at the top of his head. But at any rate he might answer questions.--How am I to get in?" [MASK] repeated, aloud.

298.passage:
she repeated, aloud.

"I shall sit here," the Footman remarked, "till tomorrow--"

At this moment the door of the house opened, and a large plate came skimming out, straight at [MASK]'s head: it just grazed his nose, and broke to pieces against one of the trees behind him.

301.passage:
--or next day, maybe," the Footman continued in the same tone, exactly as if nothing had happened.

"How am I to get in?" asked [MASK] again, in a louder tone.

"_Are_ you to get in at all?" said the Footman.

303.passage:
_Are_ you to get in at all?" said the Footman. "That's the first question, you know."

It was, no doubt: only [MASK] did not like to be told so.

308.passage:
I shall sit here," he said, "on and off, for days and days."

"But what am _I_ to do?" said [MASK].

"Anything you like," said the Footman, and began whistling.

310.passage:
Anything you like," said the Footman, and began whistling.

"Oh, there's no use in talking to him," said [MASK] desperately: "he's perfectly idiotic!" And she opened the door and went in.

312.passage:
The door led right into a large kitchen, which was full of smoke from one end to the other: the Duchess was sitting on a three-legged stool in the middle, nursing a baby; the cook was leaning over the fire, stirring a large cauldron which seemed to be full of soup.

"There's certainly too much pepper in that soup!" [MASK] said to herself, as well as she could for sneezing.

313.passage:
The only things in the kitchen that did not sneeze, were the cook, and a large cat which was sitting on the hearth and grinning from ear to ear.

"Please would you tell me," said [MASK], a little timidly, for she was not quite sure whether it was good manners for her to speak first, "why your cat grins like that?"

"It's a Cheshire cat," said the Duchess, "and that's why.

323.passage:
The Duchess took no notice of them even when they hit her; and the baby was howling so much already, that it was quite impossible to say whether the blows hurt it or not.

"Oh, _please_ mind what you're doing!" cried [MASK], jumping up and down in an agony of terror. "Oh, there goes his _precious_ nose!" as an unusually large saucepan flew close by it, and very nearly carried it off.

325.passage:
Oh, there goes his _precious_ nose!" as an unusually large saucepan flew close by it, and very nearly carried it off.

"If everybody minded their own business," the Duchess said in a hoarse growl, "the world would go round a deal faster than it does."

"Which would _not_ be an advantage," said [MASK], who felt very glad to get an opportunity of showing off a little of her knowledge.

329.passage:
Just think of what work it would make with the day and night! You see the earth takes twenty-four hours to turn round on its axis--"

"Talking of axes," said the Duchess, "chop off her head!"

[MASK] glanced rather anxiously at the cook, to see if she meant to take the hint; but the cook was busily stirring the soup, and seemed not to be listening, so she went on again: "Twenty-four hours, I _think_; or is it twelve?

335.passage:
(In which the cook and the baby joined):


"Wow! wow! wow!"


While the Duchess sang the second verse of the song, she kept tossing the baby violently up and down, and the poor little thing howled so, that [MASK] could hardly hear the words:--

"I speak severely to my boy,     I beat him when he sneezes; For he can thoroughly enjoy     The pepper when he pleases!"


CHORUS.

336.passage:
Wow! wow! wow!"


"Here! you may nurse it a bit, if you like!" the Duchess said to [MASK], flinging the baby at her as she spoke.

339.passage: As soon as she had made out the proper way of nursing it, (which was to twist it up into a sort of knot, and then keep tight hold of its right ear and left foot, so as to prevent its undoing itself,) she carried it out into the open air. "If I don't take this child away with me," thought [MASK], "they're sure to kill it in a day or two: wouldn't it be murder to leave it behind?" She said the last words out loud, and the little thing grunted in reply (it had left off sneezing by this time).

344.passage: No, there were no tears. "If you're going to turn into a pig, my dear," said [MASK], seriously, "I'll have nothing more to do with you. Mind now!

353.passage:
Would you tell me, please, which way I ought to go from here?"

"That depends a good deal on where you want to get to," said the Cat.

"I don't much care where--" said [MASK].

362.passage:
What sort of people live about here?"

"In _that_ direction," the Cat said, waving its right paw round, "lives a Hatter: and in _that_ direction," waving the other paw, "lives a March Hare. Visit either you like: they're both mad."

"But I don't want to go among mad people," [MASK] remarked.

378.passage:
Do you play croquet with the Queen to-day?"

"I should like it very much," said [MASK], "but I haven't been invited yet."

"You'll see me there," said the Cat, and vanished.

382.passage:
By-the-bye, what became of the baby?" said the Cat. "I'd nearly forgotten to ask."

"It turned into a pig," [MASK] quietly said, just as if it had come back in a natural way.

432.passage:
[MASK] remarked. "It tells the day of the month, and doesn't tell what o'clock it is!"

"Why should it?" muttered the Hatter.

435.passage:
Does _your_ watch tell you what year it is?"

"Of course not," [MASK] replied very readily: "but that's because it stays the same year for such a long time together."

"Which is just the case with _mine_," said the Hatter.

451.passage:
I don't know what you mean," said [MASK].

"Of course you don't!" the Hatter said, tossing his head contemptuously.

456.passage:
Ah! that accounts for it," said [MASK]. "He won't stand beating. Now, if you only kept on good terms with him, he'd do almost anything you liked with the clock. For instance, suppose it were nine o'clock in the morning, just time to begin lessons: you'd only have to whisper a hint to Time, and round goes the clock in a twinkling! Half-past one, time for dinner!"

("I only wish it was," the March Hare said to itself in a whisper.)

457.passage:
Half-past one, time for dinner!"

("I only wish it was," the March Hare said to itself in a whisper.)

"That would be grand, certainly," said [MASK] thoughtfully: "but then--I shouldn't be hungry for it, you know.

467.passage:
How I wonder what you're at!'


You know the song, perhaps?"

"I've heard something like it," said [MASK].

"It goes on, you know," the Hatter continued, "in this way:--

'Up above the world you fly, Like a tea-tray in the sky.

536.passage:
At any rate I'll never go _there_ again!" said [MASK] as she picked her way through the wood. "It's the stupidest tea-party I ever was at in all my life!"

Just as she said this, she noticed that one of the trees had a door leading right into it.

537.passage: Just as she said this, she noticed that one of the trees had a door leading right into it. "That's very curious!" [MASK] thought.

545.passage:
_You'd_ better not talk!" said [MASK]. "I heard the Queen say only yesterday you deserved to be beheaded!"

"What for?" said the one who had spoken first.

557.passage:
So she stood still where she was, and waited.

When the procession came opposite to [MASK], they all stopped and looked at her, and the Queen said severely "Who is this?" She said it to the Knave of Hearts, who only bowed and smiled in reply.

562.passage:
I needn't be afraid of them!"

"And who are _these?_" said the Queen, pointing to the three gardeners who were lying round the rose-tree; for, you see, as they were lying on their faces, and the pattern on their backs was the same as the rest of the pack, she could not tell whether they were gardeners, or soldiers, or courtiers, or three of her own children.

"How should _I_ know?" said [MASK], surprised at her own courage.

569.passage:
[MASK] did so, very carefully, with one foot.

"Get up!" said the Queen, in a shrill, loud voice, and the three gardeners instantly jumped up, and began bowing to the King, the Queen, the royal children, and everybody else.

"Leave off that!" screamed the Queen.

580.passage:
the soldiers shouted in reply.

"That's right!" shouted the Queen. "Can you play croquet?"

The soldiers were silent, and looked at [MASK], as the question was evidently meant for her.

584.passage:
She was walking by the White Rabbit, who was peeping anxiously into her face.

"Very," said [MASK]: "--where's the Duchess?"

"Hush!

587.passage:
Hush!" said the Rabbit in a low, hurried tone. He looked anxiously over his shoulder as he spoke, and then raised himself upon tiptoe, put his mouth close to her ear, and whispered "She's under sentence of execution."

"What for?" said [MASK].

590.passage:
the Rabbit asked.

"No, I didn't," said [MASK]: "I don't think it's at all a pity. I said 'What for?'"

"She boxed the Queen's ears--" the Rabbit began.

595.passage:
The Queen will hear you! You see, she came rather late, and the Queen said--"

"Get to your places!" shouted the Queen in a voice of thunder, and people began running about in all directions, tumbling up against each other; however, they got settled down in a minute or two, and the game began. [MASK] thought she had never seen such a curious croquet-ground in her life; it was all ridges and furrows; the balls were live hedgehogs, the mallets live flamingoes, and the soldiers had to double themselves up and to stand on their hands and feet, to make the arches.

613.passage:
It's a friend of mine--a Cheshire Cat," said [MASK]: "allow me to introduce it."

"I don't like the look of it at all," said the King: "however, it may kiss my hand if it likes."

"I'd rather not," the Cat remarked.

616.passage:
"I'd rather not," the Cat remarked.

"Don't be impertinent," said the King, "and don't look at me like that!" He got behind [MASK] as he spoke.

619.passage:
A cat may look at a king," said [MASK]. "I've read that in some book, but I don't remember where."

"Well, it must be removed," said the King very decidedly, and he called the Queen, who was passing at the moment, "My dear!

621.passage:
I've read that in some book, but I don't remember where."

"Well, it must be removed," said the King very decidedly, and [MASK] called the Queen, who was passing at the moment, "My dear! I wish you would have this cat removed!"

The Queen had only one way of settling all difficulties, great or small.

622.passage: The Queen had only one way of settling all difficulties, great or small. "Off with his head!" [MASK] said, without even looking round.

627.passage:
[MASK] could think of nothing else to say but "It belongs to the Duchess: you'd better ask _her_ about it."

"She's in prison," the Queen said to the executioner: "fetch her here." And the executioner went off like an arrow.

634.passage:
I can't tell you just now what the moral of that is, but I shall remember it in a bit."

"Perhaps it hasn't one," [MASK] ventured to remark.

"Tut, tut, child!" said the Duchess.

636.passage: Tut, tut, child!" said the Duchess. "Everything's got a moral, if only you can find it." And she squeezed herself up closer to [MASK]'s side as she spoke.

638.passage:
The game's going on rather better now," she said, by way of keeping up the conversation a little.

"'Tis so," said the Duchess: "and the moral of that is--'Oh, 'tis love, 'tis love, that makes the world go round!'"

"Somebody said," [MASK] whispered, "that it's done by everybody minding their own business!"

"Ah, well!

647.passage:
Shall I try the experiment?"

"He might bite," [MASK] cautiously replied, not feeling at all anxious to have the experiment tried.

"Very true," said the Duchess: "flamingoes and mustard both bite.

659.passage:
It doesn't look like one, but it is."

"I quite agree with you," said the Duchess; "and the moral of that is--'Be what you would seem to be'--or if you'd like it put more simply--'Never imagine yourself not to be otherwise than what it might appear to others that what you were or might have been was not otherwise than what you had been would have appeared to them to be otherwise.'"

"I think I should understand that better," [MASK] said very politely, "if I had it written down: but I can't quite follow it as you say it."

"That's nothing to what I could say if I chose," the Duchess replied, in a pleased tone.

663.passage:
That's nothing to what I could say if I chose," the Duchess replied, in a pleased tone.

"Pray don't trouble yourself to say it any longer than that," said [MASK].

"Oh, don't talk about trouble!" said the Duchess.

665.passage:
Oh, don't talk about trouble!" said the Duchess. "I make you a present of everything I've said as yet."

"A cheap sort of present!" thought [MASK].

669.passage:
the Duchess asked, with another dig of her sharp little chin.

"I've a right to think," said [MASK] sharply, for she was beginning to feel a little worried.

"Just about as much right

671.passage:
Just about as much right," said the Duchess, "as pigs have to fly; and the m--"

But here, to [MASK]'s great surprise, the Duchess's voice died away, even in the middle of her favourite word 'moral,' and the arm that was linked into hers began to tremble.

672.passage:
[MASK] looked up, and there stood the Queen in front of them, with her arms folded, frowning like a thunderstorm.

"A fine day, your Majesty!" the Duchess began in a low, weak voice.

692.passage:
Why, _she_," said [MASK]. "It's all her fancy, that: they never executes nobody, you know. Come on!"

"Everybody says 'come on!'

701.passage: So they sat down, and nobody spoke for some minutes. [MASK] thought to herself, "I don't see how he can _ever_ finish, if he doesn't begin." But she waited patiently.

761.passage:
[MASK] went on eagerly.

"That's enough about lessons," the Gryphon interrupted in a very decided tone: "tell her something about the games now."




CHAPTER X.

805.passage:
I don't know where Dinn may be," said the Mock Turtle, "but if you've seen them so often, of course you know what they're like."

"I believe so," [MASK] replied thoughtfully. "They have their tails in their mouths--and they're all over crumbs.

810.passage:
But they _have_ their tails in their mouths; and the reason is--" here the Mock Turtle yawned and shut his eyes.--"Tell her about the reason and all that," he said to [MASK].

"The reason is," said the Gryphon, "that they _would_ go with the lobsters to the dance. So they got thrown out to sea.

817.passage:
I never thought about it," said [MASK]. "Why?"

"_

857.passage:
But about his toes?" [MASK] persisted. "How _could_ he turn them out with his nose, you know?"

"It's the first position in dancing.

871.passage:
What trial is it?" [MASK] panted as she ran; but the Gryphon only answered "Come on!" and ran the faster, while more and more faintly came, carried on the breeze that followed them, the melancholy words:--

"Soo--oop of the e--e--evening,     Beautiful, beautiful Soup!"




CHAPTER XI. Who Stole the Tarts?

878.passage: And that's the jury-box," thought [MASK], "and those twelve creatures," (she was obliged to say "creatures," you see, because some of them were animals, and some were birds,) "I suppose they are the jurors." She said this last word two or three times over to herself, being rather proud of it: for she thought, and rightly too, that very few little girls of her age knew the meaning of it at all.

890.passage:
There's a great deal to come before that!"

"Call the first witness," said the King; and [MASK] blew three blasts on the trumpet, and called out, "First witness!"

The first witness was the Hatter.

892.passage:
He came in with a teacup in one hand and a piece of bread-and-butter in the other. "I beg pardon, your Majesty," [MASK] began, "for bringing these in: but I hadn't quite finished my tea when I was sent for."

"You ought to have finished," said the King.

895.passage:
You ought to have finished," said the King. "When did you begin?"

[MASK] looked at the March Hare, who had followed him into the court, arm-in-arm with the Dormouse.

904.passage:
_Stolen!_" the King exclaimed, turning to the jury, who instantly made a memorandum of the fact.

"I keep them to sell," [MASK] added as an explanation; "I've none of my own. I'm a hatter."

Here the Queen put on her spectacles, and began staring at the Hatter, who turned pale and fidgeted.

919.passage:
Give your evidence," the King repeated angrily, "or I'll have you executed, whether you're nervous or not."

"I'm a poor man, your Majesty," the Hatter began, in a trembling voice, "--and I hadn't begun my tea--not above a week or so--and what with the bread-and-butter getting so thin--and the twinkling of the tea--"

"The twinkling of the _what?_" said the King.

"It _began_ with the tea," [MASK] replied.

936.passage:
That I can't remember," said [MASK].

"You _must_ remember," remarked the King, "or I'll have you executed."

The miserable Hatter dropped his teacup and bread-and-butter, and went down on one knee.

938.passage:
The miserable Hatter dropped his teacup and bread-and-butter, and went down on one knee. "I'm a poor man, your Majesty," [MASK] began.

"You're a _very_ poor _speaker_," said the King.

941.passage:
I'm glad I've seen that done," thought [MASK]. "I've so often read in the newspapers, at the end of trials, "There was some attempts at applause, which was immediately suppressed by the officers of the court," and I never understood what it meant till now."

"If that's all you know about it, you may stand down," continued the King.

949.passage:
Now we shall get on better."

"I'd rather finish my tea," said [MASK], with an anxious look at the Queen, who was reading the list of singers.

"You may go," said the King, and the Hatter hurriedly left the court, without even waiting to put his shoes on.

951.passage:
You may go," said the King, and the Hatter hurriedly left the court, without even waiting to put his shoes on.

"--and just take his head off outside," the Queen added to one of the officers: but [MASK] was out of sight before the officer could get to the door.

"Call the next witness!" said the King.

953.passage:
She carried the pepper-box in her hand, and [MASK] guessed who it was, even before she got into the court, by the way the people near the door began sneezing all at once.

"Give your evidence," said the King.

"Shan't," said the cook.

958.passage:
Well, if I must, I must," the King said, with a melancholy air, and, after folding his arms and frowning at the cook till his eyes were nearly out of sight, he said in a deep voice, "What are tarts made of?"

"Pepper, mostly," said the cook.

"[MASK]," said a sleepy voice behind her.

973.passage:
As soon as the jury had a little recovered from the shock of being upset, and their slates and pencils had been found and handed back to them, they set to work very diligently to write out a history of the accident, all except the Lizard, who seemed too much overcome to do anything but sit with its mouth open, gazing up into the roof of the court.

"What do you know about this business?" the King said to [MASK].

976.passage:
Nothing _whatever?_" persisted the King.

"Nothing whatever," said [MASK].

"That's very important," the King said, turning to the jury.

984.passage:
_I'm_ not a mile high," said [MASK].

"You are," said the King.

"Nearly two miles high," added the Queen.

986.passage:
Nearly two miles high," added the Queen.

"Well, I shan't go, at any rate," said [MASK]: "besides, that's not a regular rule: you invented it just now."

"It's the oldest rule in the book," said the King.

991.passage:
Consider your verdict," he said to the jury, in a low, trembling voice.

"There's more evidence to come yet, please your Majesty," said [MASK], jumping up in a great hurry; "this paper has just been picked up."

"What's in it?" said the Queen.

994.passage:
What's in it?" said the Queen.

"I haven't opened it yet," said [MASK], "but it seems to be a letter, written by the prisoner to--to somebody."

"It must have been that," said the King, "unless it was written to nobody, which isn't usual, you know.

1000.passage:
It isn't directed at all," said [MASK]; "in fact, there's nothing written on the _outside_." He unfolded the paper as he spoke, and added "It isn't a letter, after all: it's a set of verses."

"Are they in the prisoner's handwriting?" asked another of the jurymen.

1004.passage:
(The jury all brightened up again.)

"Please your Majesty," said [MASK], "I didn't write it, and they can't prove I did: there's no name signed at the end."

"If you didn't sign it," said the King, "that only makes the matter worse.

1008.passage:
There was a general clapping of hands at this: it was the first really clever thing the King had said that day.

"That _proves_ his guilt," said the Queen.

"It proves nothing of the sort!" said [MASK].

1011.passage:
Why, you don't even know what they're about!"

"Read them," said the King.

[MASK] put on his spectacles.

1013.passage:
he asked.

"Begin at the beginning," the King said gravely, "and go on till you come to the end: then stop."

These were the verses [MASK] read:--

"They told me you had been to her,     And mentioned me to him:

1015.passage:
For this must ever be A secret, kept from all the rest,     Between yourself and me."


"That's the most important piece of evidence we've heard yet," said the King, rubbing his hands; "so now let the jury--"

"If any one of them can explain it," said [MASK], (she had grown so large in the last few minutes that she wasn't a bit afraid of interrupting him,) "I'll give him sixpence.

1022.passage: And yet I don't know," he went on, spreading out the verses on his knee, and looking at them with one eye; "I seem to see some meaning in them, after all. "--_said I could not swim_--" you can't swim, can you?" he added, turning to [MASK].

1024.passage:
(Which he certainly did _not_, being made entirely of cardboard.)

"All right, so far," said the King, and he went on muttering over the verses to himself: "'_We know it to be true_--' that's the jury, of course--'_I gave her one, they gave him two_--' why, that must be what he did with the tarts, you know--"

"But, it goes on '_they all returned from him to you_,'" said [MASK].

1031.passage:
he said to the Queen.

"Never!" said the Queen furiously, throwing an inkstand at [MASK] as she spoke. (The unfortunate little Bill had left off writing on his slate with one finger, as he found it made no mark; but he now hastily began again, using the ink, that was trickling down his face, as long as it lasted.)

1036.passage:
No, no!" said the Queen. "Sentence first--verdict afterwards."

"Stuff and nonsense!" said [MASK] loudly.

1039.passage:
The idea of having the sentence first!"

"Hold your tongue!" said the Queen, turning purple.

"I won't!" said [MASK].

1043.passage:
Who cares for you?" said [MASK], (she had grown to her full size by this time.) "You're nothing but a pack of cards!"

At this the whole pack rose up into the air, and came flying down upon her: she gave a little scream, half of fright and half of anger, and tried to beat them off, and found herself lying on the bank, with her head in the lap of her sister, who was gently brushing away some dead leaves that had fluttered down from the trees upon her face.
